title: Marie Curie
blurb: Pioneer of radioactivity, she won two Nobel Prizes for her work in physics and chemistry.
angles: ["How did Curie's discoveries change science?","What challenges did she face as a woman in science?"]
seed_context: Born in 1867 in Warsaw, Curie moved to Paris for studies.\nShe discovered polonium and radium, advancing medical and scientific research.

title: Albert Einstein
blurb: Physicist famous for the theory of relativity, revolutionizing our understanding of space and time.
angles: ["Why is relativity important?","How did Einstein's ideas challenge classical physics?"]
seed_context: Born in 1879 in Germany, Einstein developed relativity.\nHe received the Nobel Prize in 1921 for work on the photoelectric effect.

title: Rosa Parks
blurb: Civil rights activist known for refusing to give up her bus seat, sparking the Montgomery Bus Boycott.
angles: ["Why was her act of defiance significant?","How did Parks inspire wider civil rights movements?"]
seed_context: Born in 1913 in Alabama, Parks became a key symbol of resistance.\nHer 1955 bus protest helped fuel the U.S. civil rights movement.

title: Leonardo da Vinci
blurb: Renaissance polymath skilled in art, science, and engineering, creator of the Mona Lisa.
angles: ["Why is da Vinci called a 'universal genius'?","How did his notebooks anticipate modern science?"]
seed_context: Born in 1452 in Italy, da Vinci painted and studied anatomy.\nHis notebooks reveal early ideas in engineering and science.

title: Nelson Mandela
blurb: Anti-apartheid leader who became South Africa’s first Black president after 27 years in prison.
angles: ["What was Mandela's role in ending apartheid?","How did he promote reconciliation?"]
seed_context: Born in 1918, Mandela fought apartheid in South Africa.\nHe served as president from 1994 to 1999 and won the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Florence Nightingale
blurb: Founder of modern nursing, she improved hygiene and patient care during the Crimean War.
angles: ["Why was sanitation so important in her reforms?","How did Nightingale change nursing?"]
seed_context: Born in 1820 in Italy, Nightingale trained as a nurse.\nHer work reduced hospital deaths and influenced healthcare worldwide.

title: Mahatma Gandhi
blurb: Indian independence leader who promoted nonviolent resistance against British colonial rule.
angles: ["Why was nonviolence powerful?","How did Gandhi inspire global movements?"]
seed_context: Born in 1869, Gandhi trained as a lawyer.\nHe led India's nonviolent struggle for independence, influencing future leaders.

title: Martin Luther King Jr.

angles: ["What made his speeches effective?","How did King shape U.S. civil rights law?"]
seed_context: Born in 1929, King was a Baptist minister.\nHe organized marches and inspired landmark legislation like the Civil Rights Act.

title: Jane Austen
blurb: English novelist whose works include 'Pride and Prejudice,' known for social commentary.
angles: ["Why are her novels still read?","What do her characters reveal about society?"]
seed_context: Born in 1775 in England, Austen wrote six major novels.\nHer stories explore class, marriage, and morality in Georgian society.

title: George Washington
blurb: First President of the United States and leader of the American Revolution.
angles: ["How did Washington set presidential precedents?","Why is he called the 'Father of His Country'?"]
seed_context: Born in 1732 in Virginia, Washington led revolutionary forces.\nHe became the first U.S. president in 1789, serving two terms.

title: Frida Kahlo
blurb: Mexican painter known for self-portraits and exploration of identity, gender, and pain.
angles: ["How did Kahlo express identity?","What symbols appear in her art?"]
seed_context: Born in 1907 in Mexico City, Kahlo overcame polio and injury.\nHer paintings explore personal suffering and cultural identity.

title: Abraham Lincoln

angles: ["Why was the Emancipation Proclamation important?","How did Lincoln preserve the Union?"]
seed_context: Born in 1809, Lincoln was a self-taught lawyer.\nAs president, he steered the Union through civil war and ended slavery.

title: Mother Teresa
blurb: Catholic nun who founded the Missionaries of Charity and worked with the poor in India.
angles: ["What motivated her work?","How did she impact humanitarian care?"]
seed_context: Born in 1910 in Albania, Teresa moved to India.\nShe served the poor in Kolkata and won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.

title: Winston Churchill
blurb: British Prime Minister during World War II, known for his leadership and speeches.
angles: ["Why were his speeches motivating?","How did Churchill influence Allied victory?"]
seed_context: Born in 1874, Churchill led Britain through WWII.\nHe was also a writer and received the Nobel Prize in Literature.

title: Harriet Tubman
blurb: Abolitionist who escaped slavery and led others to freedom via the Underground Railroad.
angles: ["Why was the Underground Railroad important?","How did Tubman show leadership?"]
seed_context: Born around 1822, Tubman escaped slavery in Maryland.\nShe guided enslaved people to freedom and worked for women's suffrage.

title: Galileo Galilei
blurb: Italian scientist who championed heliocentrism and improved the telescope.
angles: ["Why did heliocentrism spark conflict?","How did Galileo improve astronomy?"]
seed_context: Born in 1564 in Pisa, Galileo supported Copernicus.\nHis telescope revealed moons of Jupiter and advanced science.

title: Cleopatra

angles: ["How did Cleopatra secure power?","What role did Rome play in her reign?"]
seed_context: Born in 69 BCE, Cleopatra VII ruled Egypt.\nShe formed alliances with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony.

title: Alexander the Great
blurb: Macedonian king who created one of the largest empires in ancient history.
angles: ["Why was his empire significant?","How did his conquests spread culture?"]
seed_context: Born in 356 BCE, Alexander was tutored by Aristotle.\nHe conquered Persia and reached India before dying at 32.

title: Oprah Winfrey

angles: ["Why is Oprah influential?","How did she change television?"]

title: Vincent van Gogh

title: Confucius

seed_context: Born around 551 BCE in China, Confucius taught ethics.\nHis philosophy shaped Chinese culture and governance.

seed_context: Born in 1847 in Ohio, Edison held over 1,000 patents.\nHe developed electric power systems and founded companies.

seed_context: Born in 1412, Joan claimed divine visions.\nShe led French troops to victory and was later canonized.

title: Amelia Earhart

seed_context: Born in 1897, Earhart set records in aviation.\nShe disappeared during a 1937 flight while attempting a world circumnavigation.

title: Nikola Tesla

seed_context: Born in 1856 in Croatia, Tesla immigrated to the U.S.\nHe pioneered AC electricity and wireless experiments.

title: Marie Antoinette

seed_context: Born in 1755 in Austria, Marie Antoinette married Louis XVI.\nShe was executed by guillotine in 1793.

seed_context: Born in 1856 in Austria, Freud developed concepts like the unconscious.\nHis work shaped therapy and literature.

seed_context: Born in 1729 in Prussia, Catherine became Empress of Russia.\nShe ruled from 1762–1796, advancing art and governance.

seed_context: Born in 1912 in London, Turing broke Enigma codes.\nHis work laid foundations for modern computing.

seed_context: Born in 427 BCE, Plato founded the Academy in Athens.\nHe wrote dialogues that shaped philosophy.
